{{infobox football tournament season | title = Uganda Cup | year = 1982 | other_title = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | country = {{UGA}} | num_teams = | defending champions = | champions = [[Kampala City Council FC]] | runner-up = [[Nile Breweries FC]] | matches = | goals = | top goal scorer = | player = | prevseason = [[1981 Uganda Cup|1981]] | nextseason = [[1983 Uganda Cup|1983]] }} {{1982 football in Uganda}} '''[[Ugandan Cup|Uganda Cup]] 1982''' was the eighth season of the main Ugandan [[Association football|football]] Cup. ==Overview== The competition has also been known as the '''Kakungulu Cup''' and was won by [[Kampala City Council FC]] who were awarded the tie after [[Nile Breweries FC]] left the field of play after 75 minutes. KCC were leading Nile 1-0 when the final was abandoned. The Nile players walked off the pitch in protest to a foul committed by KCC’s John Latigo on Moses Musoke. The Nile players wanted the referee to send off Latigo, but the referee gave Latigo a caution. This annoyed Nile players and they walked off the pitch leaving KCC to be awarded the trophy.{{cite web |url= http://observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4807&Itemid=80|title= Inconsistency, impatient fans killed Nile FC |work=The Observer |accessdate=2014-01-23}} The results are not available for the earlier rounds{{cite news |title= Uganda - List of Cup Finals - RSSSF (Mikael Jönsson, Ian King and Hans Schöggl) |publisher=RSSSF Archive |year=1997–2013 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tableso/oegcuphist.html |accessdate=2014-01-22}}{{cite web |url= http://www.kawowo.com/index.php/football/item/13292-uganda-cup-past-finalists.html|title= Uganda Cup Past Finalists |work=Kawowo Sports |accessdate=2014-01-22}}{{cite web |url= http://soccer256.com/Kakungulu%20Cup%20winners.htm|title= Tournaments: Kakungulu cup |work=Soccer256 Magazine |accessdate=2014-01-22}} ==Final== {{Col-start}} {{Col-2}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:80%; font-size:100%" ! style= width="80px" |Tie no ! style= width="300px" |Team 1 ! style= width="80px" |Score ! style= width="300px" |Team 2 ! style= width="300px" | |- | 1 | '''[[Kampala City Council FC]]''' | 1–0
abandoned | [[Nile Breweries FC]] | Nile walked off in the 75th minute at 1-0. KCC were awarded the match. |} {{Col-end}} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.rsssf.com/tableso/oegcuphist.html Uganda - List of Cup Finals - RSSSF (Mikael Jönsson, Ian King and Hans Schöggl)] {{1982 in African football (CAF)}} {{Football in Uganda}} {{Uganda Cup}} [[Category:Ugandan Cup]] [[Category:1982 domestic association football cups|Uganda Cup]] [[Category:1982 in Ugandan football|Cup]] {{Uganda-sport-stub}}

{{sources|date=May 2013}} '''AS Indenié Abengourou''' is an [[Côte d'Ivoire|Ivorian]] [[Association football|football]] club from [[Abengourou]] founded in 1951.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[RSSSF]]|title=Ivory Coast - List of Foundation Dates|author=Schöggl, Hans|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/ivofound.html|date=5 March 2015}}</ref> They were promoted to the highest level of football in Ivory Coast. 3,000 capacity [[Stade Henri Konan Bédié]] is their home ground.
==Honours== *'''[[Côte d'Ivoire Premier Division]]: 0'''
*'''[[Côte d'Ivoire Cup]]: 1''' :: 1988.
*'''[[Coupe de la Ligue de Côte d'Ivoire]]: 1''' :: 2017.
*'''[[Coupe Houphouët-Boigny]]: 0'''

{{Refimprove|date=April 2011}} [[Image:Baseball pitch release.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A U.S. Naval Academy pitcher wearing stirrups]]
'''Stirrups''' were [[Baseball uniform|uniform]] socks commonly worn by [[baseball]] players up until the mid-1990s, when major-league players began wearing their pants down to the ankles, setting a trend soon picked up by players in minor and amateur leagues. Until then, stirrup socks had been an integral part of the traditional [[baseball uniform]], giving them a distinctive look. A high sock was needed because baseball players wore [[Knickerbockers (clothing)|knickerbockers]] ("knickers"), worn by many boys in the late 19th century and into the 20th century. The stirrup socks served to display team colors, stripes or team logos. For example, for several years the [[Minnesota Twins]] wore navy-blue stirrups with "TC" on the side, for "Twin Cities", and in 1987 an "m" was placed on side. The [[Houston Astros]] wore navy blue stirrup socks with an orange star on the side. The stirrup sock colors were also the basis of team names, including the [[Cincinnati Red Stockings]], [[Boston Red Sox]], and [[Chicago White Sox]]. For these reasons, traditionalists lament the recent "sockless" look in baseball uniforms.
Stirrup socks are worn on top of long socks called "sanitaries," usually white in color.<ref name=BaseballAndSocks>'''''At''''' [http://articles.philly.com/2011-08-29/sports/29941646_1_pants-socks-cuffs Baseball and socks appeal]. Vitez, Michael (August 29, 2011). Philly.com. ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''. Retrieved 2011-09-02. "This led to the invention of the two-in-one, a white sock with a colored stripe down the side, an innovation that all but ensured the demise of the stirrup."</ref> This is because early color dyes in the outer stirrup sock were thought to pose health issues,<ref name=BaseballAndSocks/> as well as the fact that the inner, less expensive white sock could be changed more frequently. The stirrup sock lacked a foot, instead having a loop ("stirrup") which fits within the arch of the foot. Over the years, the stirrup loop tended to get longer, exposing more of the white undersock, thus creating a look unique to baseball.
However, by the 1980s many players were pulling the loop so high that only the white undersock and the loop itself showed - the rest of the game sock being hidden by their pants. Eventually, this reached a point where some players only wore vertical lines for stirrups. For many years teams had enforced rules so that uniforms were worn "uniformly", including team socks. For example, [[Leo Durocher]], longtime manager of the [[Chicago Cubs]], had a measuring stick in the clubhouse. Players were required to match the length of their stirrup loops to this stick at about 4 inches, exposing only a small part of the white sanitary. Increasingly lax regulation of uniform codes by [[Major League Baseball]] eventually contributed to players ignoring the traditional look.
The [[Official Baseball Rules]] are silent on stirrups, but the fact that some players on a team wear them while others do not seems to be in violation of Rule 1.11(a)(1) which states that “all players on a team shall wear uniforms identical in color, trim and style,” as well as Rule 1.11(a)(3) that states “no player whose uniform does not conform to that of his teammates shall be permitted to participate in a game.”<ref>Baseball Explained by Phillip Mahony, McFarland Books, 2014. See [http://www.baseballexplained.com www.baseballexplained.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813034018/http://www.baseballexplained.com/ |date=2014-08-13 }}</ref>The freedom to wear high stirrups or not is remarkable considering how nowadays uniformity is otherwise enforced by MLB. For example, during a 2007 game against the [[Yankees]], with the Yankees threatening to score, [[Red Sox]] manager [[Terry Francona]] was suddenly called away from the game and questioned by a league executive as to whether he was wearing the required uniform jersey beneath his blue pullover. He wasn’t pleased.<ref>Baseball Explained by Phillip Mahony, McFarland Books, 2014. See [http://www.baseballexplained.com www.baseballexplained.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813034018/http://www.baseballexplained.com/ |date=2014-08-13 }}</ref>
Although some teams — particularly college teams — continue to wear traditional baseball stirrup socks, another option has been to replace the stirrup/undersock with a "2 in 1" combination sock<ref name=BaseballAndSocks/> that mimics the real thing, or simply to wear a single solid knee-high sock with knickers. The trend back to knickers and high socks is particularly evident among youth and high-school teams. A few pro players, such as [[Taijuan Walker]] of the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], [[Derek Holland]] of the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]], [[Melvin Upton, Jr.]] of the [[San Diego Padres]], [[Bryce Harper]] & [[Casey Janssen]] of the [[Washington Nationals]], [[Daniel Descalso]] of the [[St. Louis Cardinals]], [[Josh Outman]] of the [[Cleveland Indians]] and [[Steve Cishek]] & [[Juan Pierre]] of the [[Miami Marlins]], [[Chris Archer]] of the [[Tampa Bay Rays]], [[J.R. Graham]] of the [[Minnesota Twins]], [[Chris Taylor (baseball) | Chris Taylor]] of the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], and [[Francisco Lindor]] of the [[Cleveland Indians]] have been spotted wearing genuine stirrups recently to much fanfare. Several players on the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] will either wear stirrups over white sanitary socks, or over red socks, as the Phillies stirrups sport their Liberty Bell logo. The minor-league [[Springfield Cardinals]] wear a 2-in-1 version of the traditional [[St. Louis Cardinals]]' game sock that looks very much like the real thing.
Other sports also use, or have used, stirrup socks, but traditionally wore a white sweat sock over, instead of under, the colored stirrup game sock (e.g. basketball, football, hockey). For many years [[Official (American football)|American football officials]] commonly wore black baseball-style stirrups as part of their uniform, although this was done away with in the 2010s as full-length pants replaced the traditional knickers. There are still some sock companies manufacturing stirrup socks for baseball and other sports, including Twin City Knitting Company in [[Conover, North Carolina]].
==See also== {{Portal|Baseball|Fashion}} *[[Baseball clothing and equipment]]

A '''Beer League''' (North American English) is a recreational league for adults to drink beer and compete in different sports. While the '''pub league''' (British English) is a form of [[sports league]] actually primarily funded by sponsorships from [[pub]]s, [[tavern]]s and [[bar (establishment)|bars]]. The bars often provide funding for a team's uniforms and equipment, and often a free drink for each player, in exchange for advertising the establishment on the uniform and usually [[naming rights]] to the team itself. Beer leagues can be of virtually any sport but are usually [[amateur sports|amateur]] and recreational in nature, not being tied to a larger competitive [[league system]], and contested by adults. The consumption of alcohol is often encouraged during the contest, as the actual competition is secondary. This is beneficial to the adults that compete in these beer league events because not only are they supporting a small business, but they are getting physical activity, all while being social. For example, with Beer League Hockey over 174,000 adults play. The special thing behind these leagues is that "It’s organized hockey in its purest form, unencumbered by money, skill, ambition, fans or advancement." <ref>Bonander, Ross. “Inside the World of Beer League Hockey.” DRAFT, 14 Dec. 2015, https://draftmag.com/beer-league-hockey/</ref>

{{Primary sources|date=September 2014}} The '''Harvard-Yale chess match''' is held annually around the time of the [[Harvard–Yale football rivalry|Harvard-Yale football game]] in November on the campus of the university hosting the football game that year. It is a relatively informal match and the schools don't typically submit the games to the [[United States Chess Federation]] for rating. Nevertheless, it is one of the highlights of the year for each school's chess club. The match typically consists of five games, pitting five current Harvard students against five current Yale students (undergraduate or graduate), with each board numbered 1 through 5 (with 1 having the strongest players and 5 having the weakest). The team with the most game points is declared the winner of the match, with a win worth 1 point, a draw worth half a point, and a loss worth 0 points. In the case of a tie, either the match is declared a tie, or a tie-breaking procedure is applied. Tie-breaking procedures applied in the past included using the result of the strongest non-drawing board as the result of the match, or using results achieved on boards numbered higher than 5 by players from each school who were not selected to be in the top five. Match details vary each year depending on the preferences of current members of each school’s chess club.
Those who play in the match are typically strong tournament players. The ratings range from around 1800 to 2400 [[United States Chess Federation|USCF]]. Players occasionally are [[FIDE]] [[International Master]]s or [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grand Masters]].
As of 2018, the champion is Harvard, after defeating Yale 4-1. ==Results== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Site !! Match format !! Tie-break !! Winner !! Score !! Harvard avg. USCF rating !! {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Athleticrace |bgcolour = #CEE3F6 |image = Kuala Lumpur Marathon.png |imagesize = 250px |caption = The official logo of the KL Marathon under Standard Chartered Bank branding |date = October |location = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] |type = Road |distance = [[Marathon]] |est = 2009 |record = Men:
{{flagathlete|[[Lilan Kiprop]]|KEN}} 2:14:45
Women:
{{flagathlete|[[Rose Nyangacha]]|KEN}} 2:34:37 |sponsor = [[Standard Chartered|Standard Chartered Bank]] |homepage = {{URL|http://www.kl-marathon.com}} }} The '''KL Marathon''' is an annual [[marathon]] event held in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]]. The event was established in 1989. It is supported by the Malaysian Amateur Athletics Union (MAAU), Federal Territory Amateur Athletics Association (FTAAA) and [[Kuala Lumpur City Hall]]. In the 26th edition of the marathon in 2017, close to 36,000 runners participated in the event.{{cite news|title=ALMOST 36,000 RUNNERS AT 9TH STANDARD CHARTERED KL MARATHON|work=[[KL Marathon]]|url=http://www.kl-marathon.com/news/47/|accessdate=13 September 2017}} [[Standard Chartered Bank]] is currently the primary sponsor of this event and has been branding it as the Standard Chartered KL Marathon since 2009. ==Course== The current route was approved by the [[Association of International Marathons and Distance Races]] and [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] and it will be utilised until 2015.{{cite web|title=Organisers aiming for a smooth KL Marathon|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?sec=central&file=/2010/5/27/central/6315422|accessdate=14 July 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2016}} The [[Dataran Merdeka]] is the starting and ending points of this marathon.{{cite web|title=36 roads closed for KL Marathon 2012 |work=[[The Malay Mail]] |url=http://www.mmail.com.my/story/36-roads-closed-kl-marathon-2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718055057/http://www.mmail.com.my/story/36-roads-closed-kl-marathon-2012 |archivedate=18 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Runners who participate this marathon will run through the notable places and landmarks in Kuala Lumpur such as [[National Mosque of Malaysia|National Mosque]], [[National Museum (Malaysia)|National Museum]], [[Kuala Lumpur Railway Station]], [[KL Sentral]], [[Mid Valley Megamall]], [[Thean Hou Temple]], [[Stadium Negara]], [[Royal Selangor Golf Club]], [[Bukit Bintang]], [[Jalan Imbi]], [[KL Tower]], [[Petronas Twin Towers]], [[Istana Budaya]], [[PWTC]], [[Malaysian Houses of Parliament|Parlimen Malaysia]] and end at [[Dataran Merdeka]].{{cite web|title=Standard Chartered KL Marathon |website=iMarathonTraining.com |url=http://digital.imarathontraining.com/race_directory/calendar/2012/6/47/standard-chartered-kl-marathon |accessdate=16 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306102026/http://digital.imarathontraining.com/race_directory/calendar/2012/6/47/standard-chartered-kl-marathon |archivedate=6 March 2016 }} Roads that are affected by the marathon race route are closed to traffic throughout the duration of the race for runners' safety.{{cite news|title=Roads closed for KL Marathon |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?file=/2012/6/15/central/11480259&sec=central |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616094159/http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?file=%2F2012%2F6%2F15%2Fcentral%2F11480259&sec=central |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 June 2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012 |df= }} Water stations are available in every two kilometres and there are 24 water stations throughout the 42-kilometre route. Volunteers and medical personnel are also on stand-by at every station. ==Winners== This list of winners below only applies to Full Marathon (42 km) only.

(Malaysia)]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/sports/story.asp?file=/2009/6/29/sports/4215799&sec=sports|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130221044726/http://thestar.com.my/sports/story.asp?file=/2009/6/29/sports/4215799&sec=sports|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 Lim Wei Yee, 25, died on the way to the hospital.{{cite news|title=Death mars KL marathon|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Malaysia/Story/A1Story20100628-224209.html|publisher=[[AsiaOne]]|date=28 June 2010|accessdate=25 April 2016}} ==Charity benefits== The marathon for [[Charity (practice)|charity purpose]] category that allows runners to raise funds for charity such as [[Seeing is Believing (organization)|Seeing is Believing]] was first organised in Kuala Lumpur Marathon on 2009 under the name "Run For A Cause".{{cite news|title=Running blind|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/lifestyle/story.asp?sec=lifefocus&file=/2009/6/3/lifefocus/3994559 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130221085547/http://thestar.com.my/lifestyle/story.asp?sec=lifefocus&file=/2009/6/3/lifefocus/3994559 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 February 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2012}} During the first charity marathon, more than [[Ringgit Malaysia|RM]] 500,000 has been earned from the event. Starting 2010, five organisation such as Malaysian Association for the Blind (MAB), Malaysian AIDS Foundation (MAF), National Cancer Society of Malaysia (NCSM), Children’s Environmental Heritage Foundation (YAWA) and Standard Chartered Trust Funds (SCTF) will be also benefited by the charity earned from this marathon event.{{cite news|title=Five charity organisations to benefit from KL marathon |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |url=http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?file=/2010/5/4/central/6159395&sec=central |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504223923/http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?file=%2F2010%2F5%2F4%2Fcentral%2F6159395&sec=central |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 4 May 2010 |accessdate=15 July 2012 |df= }} In addition, the Corporate Challenge, similar to "Run For A Reason" charity marathon category was also introduced but this category is open to the company that run in a team.{{cite news|title=Standard Chartered KL Marathon aims to attract 25,000 runners this year|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?sec=central&file=/2011/3/26/central/8284316|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130221091210/http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?sec=central&file=/2011/3/26/central/8284316|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 February 2013|accessdate=15 July 2012}} In 2011 marathon, a total of RM 486,668 has been raised for charity purpose. The contributor to the 2011 marathon charity fund will include the company [[Petronas|Petronas Chemicals Group]] (RM 30,000) and [[Freescale Semiconductor|Freescale Semiconductor (Malaysia)]] (RM 20,000).{{cite news|title=‘Run For a Cause’ raises RM486,668|work=[[The Sun (Malaysia)]]|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/85213|accessdate=16 July 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== *[http://www.kl-marathon.com Official site of KL Marathon] {{Standard Chartered}} [[Category:Standard Chartered]] [[Category:Marathons in Malaysia]] [[Category:Sport in Kuala Lumpur]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 2009]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Les Miller Field at Curtis Granderson Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = Les Miller Field (1996–2013) | location = 901 West Roosevelt Road, [[Chicago, Illinois]], USA | coordinates = {{coord|41.865027|-87.64936|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = 1996 | opened = 4 May 1996 | renovated = 2010, 2014 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Illinois at Chicago]] | operator = University of Illinois at Chicago | surface = [[Artificial turf]] | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 1,000 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = 330 feet ([[Left field|LF]])
374 feet (LCF)
401 feet ([[Baseball field#outfield|CF]])
374 feet (RCF)
330 feet ([[Right field|RF]]) | acreage = | tenants = [[UIC Flames baseball]] ([[Horizon League|HL]]) (1996–present) }} '''Les Miller Field at Curtis Granderson Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Chicago, Illinois]], United States. It is home to the [[UIC Flames baseball]] team of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Horizon League]]. The facility has a capacity of 1,000 spectators and is named for [[Les Miller (baseball coach)|Les Miller]], UIC head baseball coach from 1949–1979, and [[Curtis Granderson]], an alumnus of the program. During Miller's tenure, the program won over 500 games. Granderson was named conference player of the year with the Flames in 2002 and later played in [[Major League Baseball]].{{cite web|title=Les Miller Field |url=http://www.uicflames.com/facilities/les.html |work=UIC Flames |publisher=University of Illinois at Chicago Athletic Department |accessdate=30 January 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/655QE9GIN?url=http://www.uicflames.com/facilities/les.html |archivedate=30 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=Former UIC Baseball Coach Les Miller Passes Away |url=http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-basebl/stories/022107aax.html |work=CSTV |accessdate=10 May 2012 |date=21 February 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67Xobc7uY?url=http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-basebl/stories/022107aax.html |archivedate=10 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On 17 September 2013, UIC broke ground on a new stadium on the same site, funded in part by donations from Granderson. It consists of a new structure housing a press box, dugouts, and grandstand, and was completed for the 2014 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.uicflames.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/091713aab.html|publisher=UIC Flames|title=Curtis Granderson Stadium Officially Breaks Ground|date=17 September 2013|accessdate=17 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.uicflames.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/092513aaa.html|title=Curtis Granderson Stadium Construction Update - Week One|publisher=UIC Flames|date=25 September 2013|accessdate=25 September 2013}} == History == In spring 1996, the construction of Les Miller Field was completed. Its first game came on 4 May 1996, against [[Wright State Raiders baseball|Wright State]]. In 1998, 1999, 2001, 2008, and 2012, Miller Field hosted the [[Horizon League]] Baseball Tournament. Also, the venue has twice hosted the National Amateur All-Star Baseball Tournament.{{cite web|last=Oren |first=Paul |title=Crusaders Win Horizon League Tourney, Head to NCAA Baseball Tournament |url=http://www.nwitimes.com/sports/college/valparaiso-university/crusaders-win-horizon-league-tourney-head-to-ncaa-baseball-tournament/article_ef9daeb3-6f45-5dc3-b8f6-bcbc65e533c5.html |work=NWITimes.com |publisher=The Times of Northwest Indiana |accessdate=28 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67zGQtuJo?url=http://www.nwitimes.com/sports/college/valparaiso-university/crusaders-win-horizon-league-tourney-head-to-ncaa-baseball-tournament/article_ef9daeb3-6f45-5dc3-b8f6-bcbc65e533c5.html |archivedate=28 May 2012 |date=27 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} === Other uses === In 1996, the field was a filming location for the film ''[[Primal Fear (film)|Primal Fear]]''. Also, scenes from the [[television show]] ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'' have been shot at the venue. In 2010, the St. Ignatius College Prep high school baseball team used the field as a temporary home.{{cite web|last=Hedger |first=Brian |title=High School Baseball: Without a Varsity Field, St. Ignatius' Bus Has Become Its Home |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-04-24/sports/ct-spt-0425-prep-base-st-ignatius-uic-20100424_1_st-ignatius-wolfpack-tiny-field |work=The Chicago Tribune |accessdate=10 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67XoRvD85?url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-04-24/sports/ct-spt-0425-prep-base-st-ignatius-uic-20100424_1_st-ignatius-wolfpack-tiny-field |archivedate=10 May 2012 |date=24 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == Features == The field's features include an [[artificial turf]] playing surface, a [[press box]], an electronic scoreboard, [[Dugout (baseball)|dugout]]s, a [[brick]] backstop, a padded outfield wall (added in 2010), restrooms, and concessions. The artificial turf surface was installed prior to the 2008 season.{{cite web|title=FieldTurf Project at Les Miller Field Nears Completion |url=http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-basebl/stories/100907aan.html |work=CSTV |accessdate=10 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67XomyFhy?url=http://www.cstv.com/sports/m-basebl/stories/100907aan.html |archivedate=10 May 2012 |date=9 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=FieldTurf It Is for UIC's Les Miller Field |url=http://www.globenewswire.com/newsroom/news.html?d=118590 |work=Globe Newswire |publisher=FieldTurf Tarkett |accessdate=10 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67XotLBbb?url=http://www.globenewswire.com/newsroom/news.html?d=118590 |archivedate=10 May 2012 |date=1 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == See also == * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Horizon League baseball venue navbox}} {{Illinois NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Chicago]] [[Category:UIC Flames baseball]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox football league | logo = | pixels = | country = {{ROM}} | confed = [[UEFA]] |founded = 1990 as Divizia B
2013 as Liga I
2017 as Liga II | teams = | divisions = 2 | promotion = [[Liga I Feminin|Liga I]] | relegation = [[Liga III (women's football)|Liga III]] | levels = 2 | domest_cup = [[Romanian Women's Cup]] | confed_cup = | champions = | season = | most_champs= | website = [http://frfotbal.ro/index.php?competition_id=94 frfotbal.ro] | current = [[2016–17 Romanian Liga I (women's football)]] }} '''Liga II''' is the second level [[women's association football|women's football]] league in Romania. A second tier women's football competition was first created in 1990 under the name ''Divizia B''. After the fall of communism, organised women's football started to take off, and the founded clubs were distributed into 2 leagues - ''Divizia A'' with 12 teams and ''Divizia B'' with 30 teams grouped into 3 series, following a tournament called ''Cupa Libertății''.{{citation|title=Celălalt fotbal | url=http://www.mygeographic.ro/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/fotbal-feminin-mic.pdf}} Some time after, the number women's clubs declined, and the division was disbanded. The second level league was reintroduced starting with the 2013–14 season, when it formally received the name ''Liga I'', following the introduction of ''Superliga'' as the top-tier league. However, as of the 2017-18 season, it was rebranded as ''Liga II'', since the ''Superliga'' brand was quietly dropped altogether.http://www.frfotbal.ro/index.php?competition_id=94 ==Format== Since it's reintroduction, Liga II has always had two parallel regional divisions. Second teams of clubs in the top league cannot promote. The promoting teams in each series for every year are denoted in italics. ==Winners== The following is a list of all Romanian women's second-tier football league winners. The first place is declared the champion of the series, promotes to Liga I, and is presented with a trophy. The top three teams currently also receive gold, silver and bronze medals from the [[Romanian Football Federation]]. {| class="wikitable" width=750px; !width=5%|Ed. !width=26%|Season !width=23%|Champions !width=23%|Runner-up !width=23%|Third place |- |1 || 2013–14 Liga I, Seria Nord || ''Heniu Prundu Bârgăului'' || Vasas Femina Odorhei || Armonia Dolhești |- |1 || 2013–14 Liga I, Seria Sud || ''CS U Alexandria'' || Viitorul Buzău || Oțelul Galați |- |2 || 2014–15 Liga I, Seria I || [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia 2 Cluj]] || ''Vasas Femina Odorhei'' || ''Independența Baia Mare'' |- |2 || 2014–15 Liga I, Seria II || ''Năvobi Iași'' || CSȘ Târgoviște || Selena Constanța |- |3 || 2015–16 Liga I, Seria I || ''CSȘ Târgoviște'' || Viitorul Reghin || Armonia Dolhești |- |3 || 2015–16 Liga I, Seria II || ''[[CFR Timișoara (women)|CFR Timișoara]]'' || [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia 2 Cluj]] || Real 2 Craiova |- |4 || [[2016–17 Romanian Liga I (women's football)|2016–17 Liga I, Seria I]] || ''U Alexandria'' || Viitorul Reghin || Selena Constanța |- |4 || [[2016–17 Romanian Liga I (women's football)|2016–17 Liga I, Seria II]] || [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia 2 Cluj]] || ''Fortuna Becicherecu Mic'' || Vasas 2 Femina Odorhei |- |5 || 2017–18 Liga II, Seria I || ''U Galați'' || Selena Constanța || Onix Râmnicu Sărat |- |5 || 2017–18 Liga II, Seria II || ''Independența Baia Mare'' || Vasas 2 Femina Odorhei || [[CFF Olimpia Cluj|Olimpia 2 Cluj]] |} {{Football in Romania}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Football leagues in Romania|Women]] {{Romania-footy-competition-stub}}

page.title: List of recipients of the Paralympic Order

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{unbalanced|date=February 2012}} {{tone|date=February 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2012}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Mitchell & Ness Nostalgia Co. | logo = Mitchell and Ness logo.png | logo_size = 300px | type = [[Subsidiary company|Subsidiary]] | industry = | foundation = 1904 (as Mitchell & Ness) | location = 235 S. 17th Street
[[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | key_people = Peter Capolino, Founder
Kevin Wulff, CEO
Glen Giovanucci, Vice President | products = | revenue = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | company_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.mitchellandness.com/ www.mitchellandness.com] }} '''Mitchell & Ness Nostalgia Co.''', is an American [[sports]] clothing company located in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. The company was established in 1904, and is the oldest sporting goods company in Philadelphia. By license agreements with [[Major League Baseball]], the [[National Basketball Association]], [[National Football League]], [[National Hockey League]], [[Major League Soccer]] and the Collegiate Licensing Company, the company has been producing vintage sports goods such as jerseys, jackets, hats, and wool-felt historic pennants. ==Company history== Mitchell & Ness Sporting Goods first opened its doors in Philadelphia in 1904.Al Hunter, Jr., "Jersey Story", ''Philadelphia Daily News'', (February 4, 2002). Frank P. Mitchell, a former AAU tennis and wrestling champ, and Charles M. Ness, an avid golfer born in [[Scotland]], together founded Mitchell & Ness Sporting Goods in 1904. Their original store made and strung hand-crafted tennis rackets and, using imported woods from Scotland, stolen from England, constructed custom-made golf clubs. In time, they expanded their business, selling uniforms to local baseball and football teams. When the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] entered the young National Football League in 1933, M&N supplied the team jerseys and equipment. Mitchell & Ness would continue to outfit the Eagles through the 1963 season. The first time that the Mitchell & Ness label appeared on a major league baseball uniform –the [[Philadelphia Athletics]]– was in 1938. In the early 1940s, M&N began to supply Philadelphia's other major league baseball team –the [[Philadelphia Phillies|Phillies]]. By the end of the decade, the Mitchell & Ness label was appearing on high school and college team uniforms throughout the Philadelphia area. In the late 1970s, Mitchell & Ness had dropped the team business to concentrate on its retail operation. The store became a leading outlet for field hockey equipment and ski gear. Mitchell & Ness almost went bankrupt in 1983. Owner Peter Capolino told the ''Detroit Free Press'', "By 1983 all the expansion I had done had gone to hell. I fired 100 people, closed two warehouses. I reduced the company to a little store at 13th and [[Walnut Street (Philadelphia)|Walnut Streets]] (in Philadelphia). It was down to just me and my wife."Michael Rosenberg, "New twist makes 'old' jerseys fashionable", ''Detroit Free Press'' (April 29, 2003). In 1985, a customer walked into the store and asked if M&N could repair his 1960 Pirates game-worn vest, and his 1949 St Louis Browns game-worn shirt. They were both made of wool flannel as all baseball uniforms had been during that era. Mitchell & Ness found that it could do it, and with the realization that M&N was capable of this task, an idea was born: Reproduce historically accurate wool-flannel baseball uniforms. Mitchell & Ness recruited history buffs and sports gurus most notably Capolino's friend Bob Downes. They dug through old newspapers, periodicals, books, programs, and old film footage. They consulted vintage uniform collectors throughout the country and visited the archives at the [[Baseball Hall of Fame]] in Cooperstown, NY. Major League Baseball teams had stopped wearing wool flannel jerseys by 1972. Teams now wear double-knit polyester jerseys. In a dusty warehouse in [[North Philadelphia]], Mitchell & Ness discovered rolls of old baseball flannel from 50 years earlier. They were still carefully wrapped, untouched, and in like-new condition ready to be cut and sewn. The flannel was sewn. The lettering and patches were recreated and applied. The jerseys were completed, and they were offered for sale. The first shirts sold almost overnight. So did the second batch of a dozen or more. In time, Mitchell & Ness attracted customers from across the United States. [[Sports Illustrated]] wrote a flattering piece about M&N in June 1987. [[The New York Times]] wrote about the company two years later. In 1999, M&N expanded into the history of the NBA when it introduced its Hardwood Classics collection of basketball jerseys. Football followed a year later with the M&N Throwback Collection. In 2002, the NHL granted M&N rights to remake vintage hockey sweaters. Mitchell & Ness now has on file every MLB uniform worn since the founding of the original [[Cincinnati Red Stockings]] in 1869. In 2007, [[Adidas]] purchased Mitchell & Ness in order to get into the retro-apparel style market.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/stories/2007/11/05/daily51.html |title=Adidas buys throwback jersey maker Mitchell & Ness |publisher=Philadelphia Business Journal |accessdate=2013-04-30}} On May 29, 2008, the Philadelphia Phillies announced that they had signed Mitchell & Ness as a naming-rights partner of its clothes store at the Phillies' [[Citizens Bank Park]]. The Mitchell & Ness Alley Store is in [[Ashburn Alley]] beyond left-center field.{{cite news | first=| last=Philadelphia Phillies| coauthors=| title=Press Release: Phillies announce new Mitchell & Ness Alley store at Citizens Bank Park| date=2008-05-29| publisher=[[MLB.com]]| url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20080529&content_id=2793349&vkey=pr_phi&fext=.jsp| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-06 | language = }} On January 24, 2011, the [[Reading Phillies]], AA affiliate of the Phillies announced that they had signed Mitchel & Ness as a naming-rights partner of its apparel store at the R-Phils' [[FirstEnergy Stadium (Reading, Pennsylvania)|FirstEnergy Stadium]]. On March 23, 2012, Jonathan Yuska was brought on as Head of Mitchell and Ness. ==Sales history== Owner Peter Capolino reported to ''Sports Illustrated'' that Mitchell & Ness had annual sales revenue of $1.5 million per-year in 1998."Style File: Vintage Jerseys", ''Sports Illustrated'', (June 3, 2002) page 18. Revenues rose to $2.2 million in 1999Darren Rovell, "Old-school is still cool with today's star athletes", ''ESPN Sports Business'', http://www.espn.com, (May 8, 2002) and were $2.8 million in 2000.Douglas Century, "In Hip-Hop, Unitas and Chamberlain Live Again", ''New York Times'', (January 5, 2003). Sales were more than $5 million in 2001 according to ESPN.com while Capolino reported annual sales of $4.5 million in 2001 to ''USA Today''.Michael Hiestand, "Sports gear so out of style it's in style", ''USA Today'', (August 20, 2002). Sales rose to $23 million in 2002. ==Popular products== Mitchell & Ness's [[Throwback uniform|throwback]] jerseys were created to reproduce classic to very modern team and player sports jerseys which are either no longer available or hard to find. Mitchell & Ness began producing [[baseball]] (Cooperstown Collection) jerseys in 1988, although the company gained popularity in the international [[retail]] [[Market (economics)|market]] ten years after with the introduction of the NBA "Hardwood Classics" line. The company later moved on to reproducing popular throwbacks of [[American football|football]] and [[NHL]] players. ''USA Today'' reported that as of May 2002, the most popular NBA players for Mitchell & Ness were Michael Jordan and Julius Erving, followed by Magic Johnson, Wilt Chamberlain, Jerry West, and Larry Bird.Kelly Carter, "Celebs live sporting life via vintage team jerseys", ''USA Today'', (May 14, 2002) page 2D. ==Philadelphia Sports== Mitchell & Ness has involved itself with Philadelphia sports history and projects. The company sponsored a Turn Back the Clock alumni game on November 21, 2003 between players from the [[1988 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1988]] [[Temple Owls men's basketball|Temple Owls]] and [[Villanova Wildcats men's basketball#1985 National Champions|1985 Villanova Wildcats]] at the [[Liacouras Center]] on the campus of [[Temple University]] in [[North Philadelphia]].{{cite web |url=http://owlsports.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/111103aaa.html|title=Owls "Turn Back the Clock" for Alumni Hoops Battle with Villanova|accessdate=2009-04-06 |work=Temple Athletics: Men's Basketball|publisher=[[CBS College Sports Network]]|date=2003-11-11}} Mitchell & Ness is partnering with the [[Betsy Ross House]] to present an exhibition opening May 22, "Play Ball! A History of Baseball in Philadelphia."{{cite news | first=Robert| last=Strauss| coauthors=| title=Baseball all around; Our Phab Phils are back, and you can get into the game at museums, murals and more.| date=2009-04-03| publisher=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]| url= http://www.philly.com/inquirer/weekend/42339177.html| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-04-06 | language = }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Merchandising licensed manufacturer== The following is a list of the vintage products made and commercialized by the company: === Jerseys, jackets and accessories === * {{flagicon|USA}} [[MLB]] - all teams, all merchandise except hats * {{flagicon|USA}} [[NBA]] - all teams * {{flagicon|USA}} [[NFL]] - all teams * {{flagicon|USA}} [[NHL]] - all teams * {{flagicon|USA}} [[MLS]] - all teams * {{flagicon|AUS}} [[National Basketball League (Australia)|National Basketball League]] - all teams (as of 2016/17 season) === Jackets only === * {{flagicon|USA}} [[NCAA]] - all teams (not vintage jerseys licensed) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mitchellandness.com Official Mitchell & Ness Website] {{Portal|Philadelphia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mitchell and Ness}} [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Sports in Philadelphia]] [[Category:Clothing brands of the United States]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Clothing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Hip hop fashion]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1904]] [[Category:Culture of Philadelphia]] [[Category:1904 establishments in Pennsylvania]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Buildings and structures in Tunbridge Wells to [[:Category:Buildings and structures in Royal Tunbridge Wells]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Nevill Ground | nickname = | image = Nevill Ground - geograph-1895670.jpg | caption = The pavilion of the Nevill Ground | alttext = The Nevill Ground pavilion | country = England | location = [[Royal Tunbridge Wells]], [[Kent]] | coordinates = {{coord|51.122|N|0.268|E|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | establishment = 1898 | seating_capacity = 6,000[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/counties/kent/8734084.stm Kent coach Paul Farbrace hails Tunbridge Wells support], [[BBC Sport]], 10 June 2010. Retrieved 2010-09-16. | owner = [[Tunbridge Wells Borough Council]] | architect = CH Strange | tenants = [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club]]
Tunbridge Wells Tennis Club
Tunbridge Wells Hockey Club | end1 = Pavilion End | end2 = Railway End | international = true | onlyodidate = 18 June | onlyodiyear = 1983 | onlyodihome = India | onlyodiaway = Zimbabwe | year1 = 1898–present | club1 = [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club]] | year2 = 1899–present | club2 = Tunbridge Wells Tennis Club | year3 = 1901–present | club3 = [[Kent County Cricket Club]] | date = 11 March | year = 2018 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/ground/57367.html CricInfo }} The '''Nevill Ground''' is a [[cricket]] ground at [[Royal Tunbridge Wells]] in the [[English county]] of [[Kent]]. It is owned by [[Borough of Tunbridge Wells|Tunbridge Wells Borough Council]] and is used by [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club]] in the summer months and by Tunbridge Wells Hockey Club in the winter. It was opened in 1898 and was first used by [[Kent County Cricket Club]] in 1901. The county has held the [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Week]] on the ground annually, despite a suffragette arson attack which destroyed the pavilion in 1913. As well as hosting over 180 of Kent's [[first-class cricket]] matches, the ground played host to a single [[One Day International]] during the [[1983 Cricket World Cup]] and was used for one match during the [[1993 Women's Cricket World Cup]]. The ground is known for being one of the more picturesque county grounds in England and particularly for having [[rhododendron]] bushes around the perimeter.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/ground/57367.html Nevill Ground], [[CricInfo]]. Retrieved 11 March 2018. It is located around {{convert|1|mi|km}} south-east of the centre of Tunbridge Wells in [[Hawkenbury, Tunbridge Wells|Hawkenbury]].[http://www.twhc.co.uk/directions2.html How to find us], Tunbridge Wells Hockey Club. Retrieved 11 March 2018. ==History== The ground was established after the purchase of the land, in 1895, by the Tunbridge Wells Cricket, Football and Athletic Club and the Bluemantle's Cricket Club on a 99-year lease from [[William Nevill, 1st Marquess of Abergavenny]]. It had formed part of his [[Eridge Park]] estate on the edge of Tunbridge Wells. Building of the ground's facilities started in 1896 and it was officially opened by the Marquess, after whom the ground was named, in 1898.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/60218.html A brief history of the Nevill Ground], [[CricInfo]]. Retrieved 11 March 2018. The original [[cricket pavilion]] on the ground was designed by local architect CH Strange and built in 1903 at a cost of £1,200.''The Builder'', vol. 104, no.1, 1913, p.504. It was destroyed in an arson attack, generally believed to have been the responsibility of militant suffragettes, in April 1913.Williamson M (2008) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/345988.html Blowing up a blind man and his dog], [[Cricinfo]], 12 April 2008. Retrieved 2018-03-11. During the [[First World War]] the ground was requisitioned by the British army to graze cavalry horses, damaging the pitch, and during the Second World War it was again requisitioned for military purposes, this time to billet soldiers.[http://www.indexmagazine.co.uk/article.php?id=612 Ton up – A century for the Kent Cricket Festival], ''[[Index Magazine]]''. Retrieved 11 March 2018. Ownership of the ground was transferred in 1946 from the Tunbridge Wells Cricket, Football and Athletic Club to Tunbridge Wells Borough Council.Purnell G (1997) [https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/johnson-ready-to-stop-the-rot-1253744.html Johnson ready to stop the rot], ''[[The Independent]]'', 2 June 1997. Retrieved 2013-01-01. In the early 20th century the county boundary between Kent and [[Sussex]] ran through the ground, the course of a stream beneath the ground marking the boundary at the time.Lawn Tennis, Sport in Brief, ''[[The Times]]'', 1908, 07-30, p.13.Aldred T (2002) [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2002/jun/03/cricket.kentccc Kent follow lead of playboy prince]. ''[[The Guardian]]'', 3 June 2002. Retrieved 2018-03-11. The rhododendron bushes around the ground are considered by cricket commentators as one of the defining images of the Nevill GroundPennell M (2012) [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/jun/06/hampshire-kent-county-championship Hamsphire struggle against Kent on a truncated day at Tunbridge Wells], ''[[The Guardian]]''. 6 June 2012. Retrieved 2018-03-11.Edwards P (2014) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/county-cricket-2014/content/story/747987.html Clouds gather over Tunbridge Wells], [[CricInfo]], 26 May 2014. Retrieved 2018-03-11. and the ground has been described as "one of the finest cricket grounds in England".Edwards P (2017) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/series/8204/report/1068605/day/3/ Kent bask in Nevill dominance with festival's future uncertain], [[CricInfo]], 28 May 2017. Retrieved 2018-03-11.Tunbridge Wells Week, ''[[The Times]]'', 1914-07-15, p.11. In 1995 a permanent covered brick stand was built, named the Bluemantle Stand after the Bluemantle's Cricket Club pavilion which had been built on the site after the fire of 1913.[http://bluemantles.com/history/ History], Bluemantle's Cricket Club. Retrieved 11 March 2018. Tunbridge Wells Borough Council has erected a temporary grandstand at the ground for some cricket weeks, sometimes funded by local businesses. [[File:Bluemantle stand Nevill Ground - geograph.org.uk - 1174829.jpg|thumb|right|alt=The side of the Bluemantle Stand|The Bluemantle Stand]] ===1913 arson=== [[File:Nevill Pavilion, Royal Tunbridge Wells.jpg|thumb|right|The Nevill Ground pavilion after the 1913 arson attack]] On 11 April 1913, the original pavilion was burnt down in an arson attack attributed to militant suffragettes. The fire was discovered by a passing [[lamplighter]] and the fire brigade extinguished the fire in an hour, too late to save the pavilion. In front of the remains of the building firemen found suffragette literature, an electric lantern and a photograph of leading suffragette [[Emmeline Pankhurst]].Moseling M, Quarrington T (2013) ''A Half-Forgotten Triumph: The story of Kent's County Championship title of 1913'', pp.117–125. Cheltenham: SportsBooks. {{isbn|978-1-907524-40-0}}.Militancy and a Cricket Pavilion, ''[[The Times]]'', 1913-04-12, p.10. It is generally believed that the fire was caused by militant suffragettes as part of a country-wide campaign of arson and other violent opposition to the withdrawal of the [[Conciliation Bills|1912 Franchise Bill]] co-ordinated by the [[Women's Social and Political Union]].Igniting Change, ''Kew'', [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]], Spring 2018, pp.49–52. The fire destroyed archives, including a print of the first [[Canterbury Cricket Week]] and the Bluemantle's Cricket Club's archives. The attack has often been linked to a comment from an unknown Kent official who is reported to have said "It is not true that women are banned from the pavilion. Who do you think makes the teas?".Moseling & Quarrington ''op. cit.'', p.118. However women were admitted to all of Kent's pavilions by 1913 and there is no evidence that the comment was ever made. There was an angry reaction to the attack locally and nationally. The [[National League for Opposing Woman Suffrage]] held a meeting in the town with Sir [[Arthur Conan Doyle]], who was a member of Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club, attending, where he called the suffragettes "female hooligans" and compared the attack to "blowing up a blind man and his dog".Lycett A (2007) ''The Man Who Created Sherlock Holmes: The Life and Times of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle'', p.363. New York City: Simon and Schuster. {{isbn|0743275233}} A new pavilion was built using the original designs after a series of fund raising concerts at the [[Opera House, Royal Tunbridge Wells|Opera House]]. Construction was finished in nine weeks, with the building completed just before the start of Tunbridge Wells Cricket Week in July 1913. ==Usage== The Nevill Ground is used regularly by [[Kent Cricket League]] team, [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club]].[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/802.html The Nevill Ground, Tunbridge Wells], CricketArchive. Retrieved 11 March 2018. It is also used during the winter by Tunbridge Wells Hockey Club as one of their venues for [[field hockey|hockey]]. It was used for [[association football]] until 1903 and was originally used for cycle racing, athletics and archery.Milton H (1979) Kent cricket grounds, in ''The Cricket Statistician'', no. 28, December 1979, pp.2–10. It is home to Tunbridge Wells Harriers, a running club,[http://www.twharriers.org.uk/about-us/ About us], Tunbridge Wells Harriers. Retrieved 11 March 2018. and the outfield was used for important lawn tennis competitions - Tunbridge Wells Lawn Tennis Club adjoins the ground.Lawn Tennis, ''[[The Times]]'', 1910-08-01, p.15.[http://www.twltc.org/tennis/about/history/ History], Tunbridge Wells Lawn Tennis Club. Retrieved 11 March 2018. [[Kent County Cricket Club]] use the ground as one of its outgrounds for at least one match each year. After a single match in 1901, the Tunbridge Wells Cricket Festival was established in 1902 and two [[first-class cricket]] matches were played every year, with the exception of the truncated 1919 season, until 1992, when the number was reduced.[http://www.tunbridgewellscc.org.uk/history/ History], [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 12 March 2018. One-day fixtures have been played on the ground in some seasons. The Nevill Ground was first used as an outground by Kent in 1901 at the behest of [[George Harris, 4th Baron Harris]]. In order to assist Kent, Tunbridge Wells Borough Council has contributed around £25,000 annually to cover the running costs of hosting Kent's games at the Nevill Ground.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/2315117/Travelling-shows-must-continue.html Travelling shows must continue], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 13 June 2007. Retrieved 2018-03-11.[https://www.timesoftunbridgewells.co.uk/council-questions-whether-county-cricket-festival-is-value-for-money/ Council questions whether county cricket festival is value for money], ''Times of Tunbridge Wells'', 14 June 2017. Retrieved 2018-03-11. The Nevill Ground was popular with Kent's players due to its surroundings and it was described by cricket historian [[EW Swanton]] as "no mean contender for the most delectable English cricket ground." In 2012, Kent's [[Friends Life t20]] match against [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] was moved to the [[St Lawrence Ground]] after the Nevill Ground was flooded after heavy rainfall leading to the 100th [[Tunbridge Wells Cricket Week]] being cut short.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-18400088 Severe weather: Thanet beaches stay closed and Kent cricket moves], BBC News, 12 June 2012. Retrieved 2018-03-11. The 2016 T20 fixture was the last one-day match to be held by Kent at the Nevill, the movement of one-day fixtures to blocks of games by the [[England and Wales Cricket Board|ECB]] meaning it was no longer considered possible to hold shorter matches at Tunbridge Wells.[https://www.timesoftunbridgewells.co.uk/no-friday-night-t20-date-for-the-nevill-next-season-2/ Nevill ground hit for six as T20 date is taken away], ''Times of Tunbridge Wells'', 7 December 2016. Retrieved 2018-03-11. Kent's match at Tunbridge Wells in [[Kent County Cricket Club in 2017|2017]] almost had to be moved to another ground due to concerns over the maintenance of the ground by Tunbridge Wells Borough Council.Tong A (2017) [https://www.timesoftunbridgewells.co.uk/cricket-festivals-future-hangs-in-balance-as-kent-complain-about-tunbridge-wells-ground/ Cricket Festival’s future hangs in balance as Kent complain about Tunbridge Wells ground], ''Times of Tunbridge Wells'', 31 May 2017. Retrieved 2018-01-31.Tong A (2017) [https://www.timesoftunbridgewells.co.uk/tunbridge-wells-cricket-club-festival-will-go-ahead/ Tunbridge Wells Cricket Festival will go ahead if pitch passes inspection], ''Times of Tunbridge Wells'', 5 December 2017. Retrieved 2018-01-31. The pitch had been left uncovered by the council's ground staff and had flooded which, combined with poor maintenance of the outfield, meant that Kent's own ground staff had to work with Tunbridge Wells Cricket Club to ensure the game could go ahead. The [[Kent County Cricket Club in 2018|2018 fixture]] at the ground was confirmed in February 2018 after a pre-season pitch inspection by Kent, subject to a further inspection prior to the match itself.Fordham J (2018) [http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent/sport/kent-to-play-at-tunbridge-159988/ Kent Cricket announce fixture at Tunbridge Wells after issues with ground addressed by council], ''Kent Online'', 12 February 2018. Retrieved 2018-02-12. ===1983 World Cup=== The Nevill Ground was used as one of the grounds for the [[1983 Cricket World Cup]], hosting one group stage match between [[India national cricket team|India]] and [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] on 18 June 1983. India's [[Kapil Dev]] scored 175 [[not out]] after the Indian side was initially reduced to 9/4. India won by 31 runs and qualified for the semi-finals, avoiding a play-off against [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/cwc2003/hi/newsid_2500000/newsid_2503000/2503081.stm Kapil clubs India to victory], [[BBC Sport]], 9 January 2003. Retrieved 2013-01-01. India went on to win the tournament – their first World Cup title.Alter J (2016) [https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/top-stories/This-day-that-year-India-win-the-1983-World-Cup/articleshow/52911427.cms This day, that year: India win the 1983 World Cup], ''[[The Times of India]]'', 25 June 2016. Retrieved 2018-04-10. Dev's [[partnership (cricket)|partnership]] of 126 runs with [[Syed Kirmani]] set a world record for the largest ninth wicket stand in ODI cricket. This match led to the Nevill Ground being held in high regard by Indian cricket fans[http://www.asianimage.co.uk/sport/2366711.kapil_dev_returns_to_scene_of_historic_innings/ Kapil Dev returns to scene of historic innings], ''Asian Image'', 26 June 2008. Retrieved 2013-01-01. with there being a view that the match inspired a change in the way cricket was played in India. Leading Indian players such as [[Sachin Tendulkar]] and [[Rahul Dravid]] have spoken about how India winning the tournament inspired them to dream of playing for their country.Premachandran D (2012) [http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/sport-comment/when-kapil-dev-made-india-believe-in-cricket When Kapil Dev made India believe in cricket], ''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]'', 17 June 2012. Retrieved 2013-01-19. There was no official television footage of the match as [[BBC]] cameramen were on strike on the day of the match,[http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/sports/kapils-175-an-epic-knock-insist-his-83-devils_10063427.html Kapil’s 175 an epic knock, insist his ‘83 Devils] ''Thaindian News'', 23 June 2008. Retrieved 2013-01-01. the Nevill Ground being ruled as too small with India and Zimbabwe being deemed too "irrelevant" for a camera crew to be sent to the match.Alter J (2008) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/355121.html Hallowed ground], [[CricInfo]], 18 June 2008. Retrieved 2013-01-01. Despite this there were reports of an Indian spectator who filmed unofficial coverage of the match with a camcorder. The tape was purchased by Dev after the match for an unknown amount,Ward J (1983) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/wc2007/content/story/280614.html Kapil Dev spares India's blushes], at [[CricInfo]], originally published 18 June 1983. Retrieved 2013-01-01. although it has been claimed that this is an urban legend and that there was no proof of this occurring. In 2008, to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the game, Dev returned to the Nevill Ground to film a news segment. Afterwards he was welcomed by representatives of Kent County Cricket Club and Tunbridge Wells Borough Council. ===1993 Women's World Cup=== The ground was one of the venues used in the [[1993 Women's Cricket World Cup]], hosting one match between [[Australia women's cricket team|Australia]] and the [[West Indies women's cricket team|West Indies]]. Australia won by eight wickets.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/67108.html 9th Match: Australia Women v West Indies Women at Tunbridge Wells, Jul 24, 1993], [[CricInfo]]. Retrieved 1 January 2013. ==Records on the ground== A total of 187 first-class matches have been held on the ground, all featuring Kent as the home side.Grounds Records in ''Kent County Cricket Club Annual 2017'', pp.210–211. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]]. Another 27 List A fixtures have been played, all but one featuring Kent as the home side, the other being the One Day International between India and Zimbabwe held during the 1983 World Cup. Kent have also played six [[Twenty20]] matches on the ground. ''All records last updated 30 March 2018'' ===First-class cricket=== *Highest total: 633/8 declared by Kent against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], 2015 *Lowest total: 25 by [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] against Kent, 1960 *Highest partnership: 323, 3rd wicket by [[Rob Key|RWT Key]] and [[Martin van Jaarsveld|M van Jaarsveld]], for Kent against [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]], 2005 *Highest individual score: 290, [[Wally Hammond|WR Hammond]] for [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] against Kent, 1934 *Best bowling in an innings: 10/127, [[Vallance Jupp|VWC Jupp]] for [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northants]] against Kent, 1932 *Best bowling in a match: 16/82, [[Tich Freeman|AP Freeman]] for Kent against Northants, 1932 The 633 runs scored by Kent against Essex in 2015 set a new record for the highest score by the county on a home ground.[http://mail.kentccc.com/news/records-tumble-at-tunbridge-wells Records tumble at Tunbridge Wells], Kent County Cricket Club, 22 July 2015. Retrieved 2015-09-30. As of 2018 it remains the fourth highest innings score in the county's history, having been surpassed in 2018 at Beckenham. Kent's [[County Championship]] match at the Nevill Ground against [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] in 1960 was, as of 2018, the last first-class match to finish in less than a day.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisiskent.co.uk/trip-memory-lane-Tunbridge-Wells/story-12129943-detail/story.html |title=A trip down memory lane at Tunbridge Wells |work=This is Kent |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=1 January 2013}} After the match, Kent's [[Colin Cowdrey]] called the pitch "disgraceful".{{cite book | first = Paul | last = Donnelly | title = First, Last & Only: Cricket| publisher = Hachette UK | location = | year = 2010| isbn = 0743275233 | page =1960 }} ===List A cricket=== *Highest total: 314/7 by [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]] against Kent, 1963 (65 over match) *Lowest total: 99 by Kent against [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]], 1996 *Highest partnership: 170, 4th wicket by [[Andrew Symonds|A Symonds]] and [[Matthew Walker (English cricketer)|MJ Walker]], for Kent against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]], 2004 *Highest individual score: 175 [[not out]], [[Kapil Dev]] for [[India national cricket team|India]] against [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]], 1983 *Best bowling: 6/49, [[Steve Barwick|SR Barwick]] for [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]] against Kent, 1995 Kapil Dev's 175 [[not out]] against Zimbabwe was a [[One Day International]] record for the highest number of individual runs scored. This record was later beaten by [[Viv Richards]].{{cite web|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JTS8yMDA4LzA2LzE4I0FyMDI5MDA=&Mode=HTML&Locale=english-skin-custom |title=All Kaps |work=Times of India |date= |accessdate=1 January 2013}} The partnership of 126 runs between Kapil Dev and [[Syed Kirmani]] set the world record for the highest ninth wicket partnership in an ODI of 126 [[not out]]. This record stood for 27 years before being beaten by [[Angelo Mathews]] and [[Lasith Malinga]] for [[Sri Lankan cricket team|Sri Lanka]].{{cite web|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283552.html |title=Highest partnership for the ninth wicket |work=ESPNcricinfo |date= |accessdate=1 January 2013}} ===Twenty20 cricket=== The highest score made in the six T20 matches held on the ground was 182/4 made by Kent in 2009 against [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]]. [[Daniel Bell-Drummond]] made the only century on the ground in T20 cricket, scoring 112 not out in 2016 against Surrey, at the same time setting a new Kent record for any partnership in T20 cricket of 151 runs with [[Sam Northeast]]. This record was beaten twice the following year by Bell-Drummond and [[Joe Denly]], although it remains a Kent record for the 2nd wicket in T20 cricket.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/county-cricket-2016/content/story/1016953.html Bell-Drummond, Denly set record in Kent opening-night win], [[CricInfo]], 20 May 2016. Retrieved 2016-05-23.[http://www.espncricinfo.com/county-cricket-2016/content/story/1035083.html Bell-Drummond's best keeps Kent hopes alive], [[CricInfo]], 15 July 2016. Retrieved 2016-07-15. ==See also== * [[List of Kent County Cricket Club grounds]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kentcricket.co.uk/grounds/the-nevill-ground/ The Nevill Ground] at [[Kent County Cricket Club]] * [http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57367.html Nevill Ground] at [[CricInfo]] {{Royal Tunbridge Wells}} {{Kent CCC|state=expanded}} {{Good article}} [[Category:Cricket grounds in Kent]] [[Category:Sport in Royal Tunbridge Wells]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1898]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Women's suffrage in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the United Kingdom destroyed by arson]] [[Category:1983 Cricket World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Royal Tunbridge Wells]]

It was part of the [[ATP Challenger Tour]]. The tournament was held in [[Nakhon Ratchasima|Khorat]], [[Thailand]] once, in 2009. ==Past finals== ===Singles=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Year !width="200"|Champion !width="200"|Runner-up !width="175"|Score |- | [[2009 SAT Khorat Open|2009]] || {{flagicon|GER}} '''[[Andreas Beck (tennis)|Andreas Beck]]''' || {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Filip Prpic]] || 7–5, 6–3 |} ===Doubles=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Year !width="200"|Champions !width="200"|Runners-up !width="175"|Score |- | [[2009 SAT Khorat Open|2009]] || {{flagicon|IND}} '''[[Rohan Bopanna]]'''

{{infobox country at games | NOC = ESP | NOCname = [[Spanish Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1956 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.coe.es }} {{es icon}} | location = [[Melbourne]]/[[Stockholm]] | competitors = 6 | sports = 1 | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = 1900 | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Spain]]''' boycotted the '''[[1956 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] because of the [[Soviet Union]]'s [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956|invasion]] of [[Hungary]]. However, the [[Equestrian at the 1956 Summer Olympics|equestrian events]] for the 1956 Games were held in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] five months earlier (because of Australian quarantine regulations), and six Spanish riders competed. ==Equestrian== {{main article|Equestrian at the 1956 Summer Olympics}} ===Eventing=== {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="3"|Athlete !rowspan="3"|Horse !rowspan="3"|Event !colspan="2" rowspan="2"|Dressage !colspan="3" rowspan="2"|Cross-country !colspan="3"|Jumping !colspan="2" rowspan="2"|Total |- style="font-size:95%" !colspan="3"|Final |- style="font-size:95%" !Penalties !Rank !Penalties !Total !Rank !Penalties !Total !Rank !Penalties !Rank |- align=center |align=left| [[Faustino Domínguez]] |align=left| Anfitrion |align=left rowspan=3|[[Equestrian at the 1980 Summer Olympics|Individual]] |170.80 |53 |colspan=3|DNF |colspan=3|DNS |colspan=3|DNF |- align=center |align=left|[[Joaquín Nogueras]] |align=left|Thalia |161.60 |49 |colspan=3|DNF |colspan=3|DNS |colspan=3|DNF |- align=center |align=left|[[Hernán Espinosa]] |align=left| Al-Herrasan |177.60 |55 |colspan=3|DNF |colspan=3|DNS |colspan=3|DNF |- align=center |align=left|[[Faustino Domínguez]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Stade de la Méditerranée | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Béziers]], [[France]] | coordinates = {{Coord|43|20|5|N|3|15|58|E|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1989 | opened = 1990 | renovated = 2003 to 2007 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of [[Béziers]] | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 18,555 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[AS Béziers Hérault]] [[AS Béziers (2007)|Béziers]] | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Stade de la Méditerranée''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Béziers]], [[France]]. The stadium is able to hold 18,555 (16110 seated)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asbh.net/stade-mediterranee/index.cfm |title=Site Officiel du Club de Rugby de Béziers - Association Sportive Béziers Hérault - Rugby Pro D2 |publisher=ASBH |date= |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref> people and was built in 1989. It is currently used mostly for [[rugby union]] matches and is the home stadium of [[AS Béziers Hérault]].
In addition to AS Béziers Hérault matches, the stadium has hosted a [[Castres Olympique]] rugby union match versus Toulouse in August 2010, and versus Stade Français in August 2014.
The stadium is also used to host [[Rugby League]] Internationals. On December 4, 1994, [[France national rugby league team|France]] hosted [[Australian national rugby league team|Australia]] in Béziers. In [[Mal Meninga]]'s last match, 8,000 people saw the Kangaroos run out 74-0 winners. More recently, Stade de la Méditerranée has been used as the home ground for the France-based [[Morocco national rugby league team|Moroccan national team]].
On 15 August 2009 Stade de la Méditerranée hosted another [[Rugby League]] game in which [[Catalans Dragons]] hosted [[Hull F.C.]] in front of 6,500 fans. Catalans Dragons ran out winners with an 18 - 6 win over Hull FC.

{{refimprove|date=May 2012}}
{{infobox martial art term |title = Throw |pic = Tomoe-nage cropped.jpg |picsize = |piccap = [[#Sacrifice throws|Sacrifice throws]] are sometimes considered risky since they put the practitioner in a potentially disadvantageous [[grappling position|position]]. }} A '''throw''', in [[martial arts]], is a [[grappling]] technique that involves off-balancing or lifting an opponent, and throwing them to the ground, in [[Japanese martial arts]] referred to as ''nage-waza'', 投げ技, "throwing technique". Throws usually involve a rotating motion, the practitioner performing the throw disconnects with the opponent, and ends balanced and on their feet as opposed to a [[takedown (grappling)|takedown]] where both finish on the ground. Throws can however also be followed into a [[grappling position#Ground grappling position|top position]], in which case the person executing the throw does not disengage from the opponent. Certain throwing techniques called '''sacrifice throws''' (''sutemi-waza'', 捨身技, "sacrifice technique") involve putting oneself in a potentially disadvantageous position, such as on the ground, in order to execute a throw.
==Types of throws== There are several major types of throw, among Asian martial arts, judo has the most developed throwing techniques and throws are considered its specialty.
Most throws are named by describing the circumvention point of the throw (e.g., hip throw, shoulder throw, wrist throw etc.), or the nature of effect of the throw on the opponent (e.g., heaven and earth throw, valley drop, body drop) with variations are given descriptive names. The names used here are attributed to Jujutsu throws (and hence judo/aikido throws) are descriptions in Japanese. It is conventional for the Japanese to name their throws in this manner, and many western martial art dojos have given English names to the throws feeling that it is easier for English speaking students to remember the names of throws if they can associate the throws by the descriptive nature of the throw name.
In judo, throws are divided into six categories—hand techniques, leg techniques, hip techniques, shoulder techniques, as well as sacrifice throws to the rear and side.
===Shoulder and Back throws=== A '''shoulder throw''' involves throwing an opponent over the shoulder. A shoulder throw which lifts the opponent from the ground is in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] referred to as ''[[seoi-nage]]'' (背負い投げ, "Back Throw"), while a throw which involves upsetting the opponents balance and pulling the opponent over the shoulder is referred to as ''seoi-otoshi'' (背負落とし, "Back Drop").<ref>The Kodokan Judo Institute. [http://www.kodokan.org/e_waza/seoiotoshi.html http://www.kodokan.org/e_waza/seoiotoshi.html] Seoi-Otoshi (hand technique)]. ''[http://www.kodokan.org www.kodokan.org]''. URL last accessed February 11, 2006.</ref> Seoi-nage is one of the most used throws in Judo competition. One study indicated that approximately 56% of [[judoka]]s implemented the technique.<ref>Weers, George. [http://judoinfo.com/weers1.htm http://judoinfo.com/weers1.htm] Skill Range of the Elite Judo Competitor]. ''judoinfo.com''. URL last accessed February 11, 2006.</ref>
A common shoulder throw is judo's [[ippon seoinage]] ("Single-Handed Back Throw")<ref>Judoinfo.com. [http://judoinfo.com/images/animations/blue/ipponseoi.htm ipponseoi]. Accessed 2012-11-28.</ref> or the similar ''flying mare'' in [[wrestling]].<ref>{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Wrestling |volume=26 |pages=844–845 |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri28chisrich#page/844/mode/1up}}</ref>
===Leg throws, reaps, and trips=== In a ''leg reap'', the attacker uses one of their legs to reap one or both of their opponent's legs off the ground. Generally the opponent's weight is placed on the leg that is reaped away. This coupled with the attacker controlling the opponent's body with their hands causes the opponent to fall over. Common leg reaps are judo's [[Ouchi Gari]], [[Kouchi Gari]], [[Osoto Gari]], and [[Kosoto Gari]] there are similar techniques in wrestling, including the inside and outside trips.
Somewhat similar to leg reaps involve a hooking or lifting action with the attacking leg instead of a reaping action. The border between the two types of throw can be unclear, and many throws will exhibit characteristics of both reaps and trips, however, the difference is that a reap is one smooth move, like that of a [[scythe]], whereas a hook is pulling the opponents leg up first, and then swinging it away. Common leg trips are hooking variations of Ouchi Gari and Osoto Gari along with [[Kosoto Gake]], referred to as inside and outside trips in Western wrestling.
===Hip throws=== A '''hip throw''' involves using the thrower's hip as a pivot point, by placing the hip in a lower position than an opponent's center of gravity. There are several types of hip throws such as O Goshi, which is often taught first to novices. Hip throws in Judo are called Koshi Waza, and in [[Aikido]] or [[Sumo]] they are called koshinage.
===Sacrifice throws=== Sacrifice throws require the thrower to move into a potentially disadvantageous position in order to be executed, such as falling to the ground. The momentum of the falling body adds power to the throw and requires comparatively little strength, compared to the effect. In Judo (as well as in other martial arts) these throws are called Sutemi Waza and are further divided into rear (Masutemi waza) and side (Yoko Sutemi Waza) throws. In Judo, these throws are limited to a specific grade and higher due to the element of danger that is placed upon both the Uke (receiver) and the Tori (thrower).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ohlenkamp|first=Neil|title=Judo Unleashed|year=2006|publisher=New Holland Publishers Ltd.|isbn=0-07-147534-6|pages=160|url=http://judounleashed.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070913064230/http://judounleashed.com/|archivedate=2007-09-13|df=}}</ref>
===Pick-ups=== Pickups involve lifting the opponent off the ground and then bringing them down again. Common pick-ups are lifting variations of the double leg [[Takedown (grappling)|takedown]], judo's [[Te Guruma]] or ''sukui nage'' (both classified as hand throws) and the suplex from wrestling, in which the attacker lifts their opponents body vertically and throws the opponent over their own center of gravity while executing a back fall (usually accompanied by a back arch). Variations of the suplex are common in most forms of [[wrestling]] and sometimes used in [[Mixed Martial Arts]] competition. In Judo the ''ura-nage'' throw is a version of the suplex, but it is importantly classified as a sacrifice throw.
=== List of throws ===
Some of the more common throwing techniques are listed below. This is not an exhaustive list and the techniques may be referred to by other names in different styles. An English translation and a common [[Japanese language|Japanese]] equivalent are given. *Hip throw ([[O Goshi]]) *Floating hip ([[Uki Goshi]]) *Rear hip throw ([[Ushiro Goshi]]) *Stamp throw *Loin and hip wheel ([[O Guruma]]) *Transitional hip throw ([[Utsuri Goshi]]) *Hip wheel ([[Koshi Guruma]]) *Sweeping hip throw ([[Harai Goshi]]) *Inner Thigh throw ([[Uchi Mata]]) *Sweeping knee throw *Sweeping ankle throw *Leg wheel ([[Ashi Guruma]]) *Outer wheel ([[Osoto Guruma]]) *Inside hook throw (Kouchi Gake) *Outer hook throw *Cross hook *Knee wheel ([[Hiza Guruma]]) *Drawing ankle throw ([[Deashi Harai]]) *Lapel Back throw ([[Eri Seoinage]]) *Single-Handed Back throw ([[Ippon Seoinage]]) *Double-Handed Back throw ([[Morote Seoinage]]) *Major inner reaping, inside trip ([[Ouchi Gari]]) *Minor inner reaping ([[Kouchi Gari]]) *Major outer reaping, outside trip ([[Osoto Gari]]) *Minor outer reap ([[Kosoto Gari]]) *Minor outer prop ([[Kosoto Gake]]) *Propping ankle throw ([[Sasae Tsurikomi Ashi]]) *Half-hip throw ([[Uki Goshi]]) *Body drop ([[Tai Otoshi]]) *Belt hip throw ([[Tsuri Goshi]]) *Sleeve-lift hip throw ([[Sode Tsurikomi Goshi]]) *Floating drop ([[Uki Otoshi]]) *Outer winding sacrifice ([[Soto Makikomi]]) *Inside wind ([[Uchi Makikomi]]) *Spring hip throw ([[Hane Goshi]]) *Double spring hip throw. *Shoulder wheel, fireman's carry ([[Kata Guruma]]) *Valley drop ([[Tani Otoshi]]) *Stomach throw ([[Tomoe Nage]]) *Side circle *Corner throw *Head hip and knee throw *Reverse head hip and knee throw *Rear head hip and knee throw *Front scoop throw *Rear scoop throw *Neck throw ([[Kubi Nage]]) *Flying scissors takedown ([[Kani Basami]]) *Flying figure ten ([[Tobi Juji Gatame]]) *Wrist-based throws, especially [[Kotegaeshi]] (forearm return / supinating wrist lock) *Figure ten throw ([[Juji nage]], not closely related to Juji Gatame) *Breath throw ([[Kokyu Nage]], sometimes called timing throw or the twenty-year throw) *Rotary throw ([[Kaiten nage]], sometimes called head-over-heels throw) *Heaven-and-earth throw ([[Tenchi nage]]) *Four corner throw ([[Shiho nage]], not to be confused with Corner Drop) *Entering throw ([[Irimi nage]], sometimes also simply called Kokyu nage (it's a specific variant))
==See also== {{Commons category|Throw (martial arts)}} * [[Judo technique]] - Includes a list of all the throws in [[Judo]] * [[Takedown (grappling)|Takedown]]

''[http://www.blackmagic.com www.blackmagic.com]''. URL last accessed February 11, 2006. * Ohlenkamp, Neil. [http://judoinfo.com/gokyo.htm http://judoinfo.com/gokyo.htm] The 67 Throws of Kodokan Judo]. ''judoinfo.com''. URL last accessed February 11, 2006. * Guresdosyasi.com. [http://www.guresdosyasi.com/samtek.html http://www.guresdosyasi.com/samtek.html] DÜNYA GÜREŞİNDE ÖNEMLİ ŞAMPİYONLARIN TEKNİKLERİ]. ''[http://www.guresdosyasi.com www.guresdosyasi.com]''. URL last accessed February 11, 2006. * [http://judoinfo.com/techjudo.htm http://judoinfo.com/techjudo.htm] "JudoInfo.com"] Videos, animations and drawings of Judo throws * [http://www.cambyjudo.ca/index.php/techniques-a-grading/throwing-techniques Collection of the 40 Throws of the Gokyo with Video Demonstrations]
