revision.text:
'''Wally''' is the name of the official mascot of the [[The Wallabies|Australian rugby union team]], [[the Wallabies]]. [[File:Wallabies-mother-and-son.jpg|thumb|right|[[wallaby|Wallabies]] in the wild]] Wally is a [[wallaby]].
The [[stuffed toy]] version of the mascot is carried with the Wallabies on overseas tours to Europe. It then becomes the duty of the youngest member of the touring party to protect the mascot from pranks by older players to hide and sabotage it. It is considered an embarrassment to the protector if Wally is not safely guarded. The protector is forced to hold Wally at all times. It becomes a source of entertainment for senior players when the team is out socialising.
==Events== When [[Berrick Barnes]] was forced to protect Wally during the 2007 World Cup in France he had to stitch it up several times and perform a search of every member's hotel room to retrieve it, despite the help of [[Lote Tuqiri]].<ref>[http://www.rugbyheaven.com.au/news/news/lote-cures-berricks-insomnia/2007/09/11/1189276644284.html Lote cures Berrick's insomnia] Greg Growden and Rupert Guinness | September 11, 2007</ref>
During the 2008 tour it became a long-running joke among the players that the mascot could be used by 18-year-old [[James O'Connor (rugby)|James O'Connor]] to break the ice with young ladies.<ref>[http://www.foxsports.com.au/story/0,8659,24559464-23217,00.html Tour rookie gets Wally] FOX Sports - October 27, 2008</ref>
In May 2007 a Welsh rugby fan was ejected from a stadium in Sydney during a match for attempting to dance with the life-size version of Wally.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/6701251.stm Fan, 72, ejected for mascot dance] BBC News</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Rugby union|Australia}} *[[List of Australian sporting mascots]]

page.title: Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox museum |image=Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center Entrance.jpg |caption=Entrance to the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center |established= {{Start date|1998|12|4}} |location=8 Yogi Berra Drive
[[Little Falls, New Jersey|Little Falls, NJ]] 07424 |architect=unknown |website={{URL|http://yogiberramuseum.org/}} }} The '''Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center''' is a museum on the campus of [[Montclair State University]] in [[Little Falls, New Jersey]]. It serves to honor the career of [[Yogi Berra]], who played for the [[New York Yankees]] of [[Major League Baseball]] and was inducted into the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame]]. The museum, which contains artifacts from Berra's career, opened on December 4, 1998. It is adjacent to [[Yogi Berra Stadium]]. ==History== [[File:Ron Guidry 05122013.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Ron Guidry]] autographing a baseball at the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center on May 12, 2013]] "The Friends of Yogi Inc.", a [[nonprofit organization]], raised $2 million through donations to build the museum to honor [[Yogi Berra]], who played his entire [[Major League Baseball]] career for the [[New York Yankees]]. [[John McMullen (engineer)|John McMullen]], the owner of the [[New Jersey Devils]] of the [[National Hockey League]], was among the museum's benefactors.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1842&dat=19980111&id=w04eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U8cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3872,1501803|title=Berra Museum opens in June|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=[[TimesDaily]]|page=20|location=[[Florence, Alabama]]|date=January 11, 1998|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} The museum was built adjacent to [[Yogi Berra Stadium]], which hosts the [[New Jersey Jackals]], a [[Minor League Baseball]] team in the [[American Association of Independent Professional Baseball]], and the Montclair State Red Hawks baseball team. The museum was dedicated in October 1998, with fellow [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]rs [[Ted Williams]] and [[Larry Doby]] in attendance.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19981025&id=9PoaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2kcEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6920,3839348|title=Hall of Famers help Yogi dedicate his museum|first=Jeffrey|last=Gold|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Bowling Green Daily News]]|page=5B|date=October 25, 1998|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} It opened to the public on December 4.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19981027&id=z2JWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4vEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6511,5576262|title=Baseball was berra, berra good to him|page=C2|work=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|date=October 27, 1998|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} In 2010, [[IKON 5 Architects]] redesigned the museum,{{cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/332797/yogi-berra-museum-and-learning-center-ikon-5-architects/|title=Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center / ikon.5 architects|work=ArchDaily}} and [[Brian Hanlon]] sculpted a statue of Berra to go in front of the museum.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/new-york/mlb/news/story?id=5215368|title=Statue of Hall of Famer Yogi Berra to stand in front of his museum|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=ESPN New York|publisher=ESPN.com|date=May 24, 2010|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} Berra had feuded with Yankees' owner [[George Steinbrenner]] since his firing 16 games into the [[1985 New York Yankees season|1985 season]]. Berra refused to have any part of Yankees events, including Yankees games.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/sep/28/sports/sp-37035|title=Berra's Exile Self-Imposed|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Mike|last=Lupica|authorlink=Mike Lupica|date=September 28, 1997|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} In January 1999, Berra and Steinbrenner resolved their feud with a public event at the Yogi Berra Museum.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/06/sports/sports-of-the-times-yogi-and-the-boss-complete-makeup-game.html|title=Sports of The Times; Yogi and the Boss Complete Makeup Game|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Harvey|last=Araton|date=January 6, 1999|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} Berra frequently visited the museum for signings, discussions, and other events. It was his intention to teach children important values such as sportsmanship and dedication, both on and off the baseball diamond.{{cite news|last=Posnanski|first= Joe|title=Yogi Berra Will Be A Living Legend Even After He's Gone|newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date= July 4, 2011|pp=64–68|volume=115|issue= 1|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1187819/index.htm}} On October 8, 2014, a [[burglary]] occurred at the museum, in which a team of "professional" thieves stole specific pieces of Berra's memorabilia.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/yankees/break-yogi-berra-museum-priceless-memorabilia-stolen-article-1.1967277|title=Break in at Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center, priceless memorabilia linked to Yankees legend stolen|first1=Bill|last1=Madden|first2=Filip|last2=Bondy|first3=Michael|last3=O'Keeffe|first4=Thomas|last4=Tracy|work=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|date=October 8, 2014|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} ==Exhibits== The museum contains items from Berra's career, including [[baseball card]]s, a jacket worn by Berra while throwing out the [[first pitch]] of Game 1 of the [[2009 World Series]], two of his [[MLB MVP]] awards, and all 10 [[World Series ring]]s he received as a player. Following the resolution of Berra's feud with Steinbrenner, the Yankees loaned the [[Commissioner's Trophy (MLB)|Commissioner's Trophy]] from the [[1998 World Series]] to the museum.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1291&dat=19990109&id=QElUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bI4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6056,2393759|title=Berra museum to show Yankees' trophy|page=2B|work=[[Boca Raton News]]|date=January 9, 1999|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} In 2013, the museum teamed up with [[Athlete Ally]] to develop an exhibit called "Championing Respect", which aims to support the inclusion of [[LGBT]] athletes in sports.{{cite news|last=Branch|first=John|title=Berra Museum to Highlight Inclusion in Sports|url=http://bats.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/01/berra-museum-to-highlight-inclusion-in-sports/|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 1, 2013|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} An exhibit in 2014 celebrated the 75th anniversary of [[Lou Gehrig]]'s farewell speech.{{cite web|url=http://m.yankees.mlb.com/news/article/93967536/new-exhibit-at-yogi-berra-museum-pays-homage-to-lou-gehrig-pete-frates|title=New exhibit pays homage to Gehrig, Frates|first=Jamal|last=Collier|work=MLB.com |date=September 9, 2014|accessdate=October 9, 2014}} The Museum offers a wide range of school and public programs on all aspects of sports and society. It conducts guided school tours and education programs, provides off-site assemblies on anti-bullying and sportsmanship, and also collaborates with Montclair State University on programs examining topical issues in media and sports. In promoting the values of respect and sportsmanship, the Museum, in partnership with Investors Bank and the Super Essex Conference, developed a Best Teammate Award program in 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/hssports/blog/football/index.ssf/2014/05/yogi_berra_honors_unsung_high_school_athletes_with_best_teammate_award.html|title=Yogi Berra honors unsung high school athletes with "Best Teammate Award" (Politi)|work=NJ.com|accessdate=September 23, 2015}} recognizing outstanding leadership by student-athletes. The Museum also offers an array of summer camps, including youth baseball and softball camps. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.montclair.edu/alumni/benefits-and-services/alumni-benefits/yogi-berra-museum-and-learning-center/|title=Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center|work=Montcialr State University}} [[Category:Montclair State University]] [[Category:Museums in Passaic County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports museums in New Jersey]] [[Category:Biographical museums in New Jersey]] [[Category:Museums established in 1998]] [[Category:Baseball museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:1998 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Little Falls, New Jersey]]
